• These parents can be counted on to be there for you, and to provide for your needs.
• You know that you can rely on these parents to support you, no matter what happens.
• You trust these parents to be there for you, to be consistent and reliable in their care and support of you.

INTEREST IN THE PATIENT

• These parents are deeply interested in you and your well-being.
• They are curious about you and your thoughts, feelings, and experiences.
• They take the time to listen to you, and to understand you.
• They are invested in your growth and development.

Behavioral Components

SOOthing

• These parents are able to soothe you when you are upset or distressed.
• They can help you to feel calm and safe, through their presence, their touch, and their words.
• They are able to help you regulate your emotions and your arousal level.

Attunement

• These parents are attuned to you and your needs.
• They can sense what you are feeling and thinking, and respond appropriately.
• They are able to adjust their behavior to meet your needs and support your well-being.

Acceptance

• These parents accept you as you are, without judgment or criticism.
• They love you unconditionally, and support you in being yourself.
• They are able to tolerate and accept your negative emotions and behaviors, without rejecting you.

Delight

• These parents find joy and delight in being with you.
• They show you that they are happy to be with you, and that they enjoy spending time with you.
• They are able to have fun and be playful with you.

Protection

• These parents protect you from harm and danger, both physical and emotional.
• They are able to set appropriate limits and boundaries, in order to keep you safe.
• They are able to advocate for you and stand up for you, when necessary.

By suggesting these qualities to the patient, the therapist helps to shape the patient’s imagery of the ideal parent figures in ways that will support the formation of secure attachment representations. The therapist can also use these suggestions to help the patient to begin to form new mental models of attachment relationships, which will be useful for the patient outside of the therapy sessions.
